Imports to the Promised Land: The Super League Exodus

20/07/2013

Robert Culshaw assesses the impact of Britain's top rugby league players choosing to ply their trade on the other side of the world

Image by

By undefined undefined

A harsh reality stares directly at British Rugby League; this reality, whether we want to believe it or not, is one that has become more and more crystallised in the world of Rugby League Football over the last decade - our domestic game just isn't the best. For the best exhibition of our sport we can no longer look to the English heartlands, but rather to the promised land of Australia, the National Rugby League and growing exodus of players heading down under. Today, the Australian NRL stands as the prime competition of Rugby League in the world; on the pitch you can expect some of the hardest, toughest and most skilled players in the sport, supported by an incredible fan base, extensive media coverage and, most significantly, more than reasonable wage packets. It is no wonder then that most British players, as well as a few coaches, aspire to end up on the other side of the world. As a result, scouts of the NRL are constantly around Super League, enticing the best and most promising domestic talent to join the exodus abroad, and why wouldn't you? Recent English imports of the last couple of years to the NRL have, if anything, hastened the arrival and increased the excitement and expectations surrounding English acquisitions, players such as England captain James Graham, the ex-St Helens prop, who joined Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs in 2012. Graham has forged his reputation as a hard running, no nonsense, prop forward with ball handling skills to rival a half-back, and is held in high esteem amongst NRL players and fans alike. However, without a doubt it is the Burgess Brothers - Sam and his younger brothers, the identical twins George and Tom - of the South Sydney Rabbitohs who have become the pace setters for any English talent moving to Australia. Sam Burgess in particular, who signed from Bradford in 2010, is now regarded as the greatest English import to the Australian game since the 1980s. Sam's ability to throw huge hits (just ask Matthew Bell) and simply to steam roll the opposition (ask Sonny Bill Williams) have gained him heroic status, one that his younger brothers have more than complimented since making their debuts. Players of that calibre are being tested by the best and the NRL has been the making of these men, and will continue to be the proving ground for any English talent. Super League just cannot seem to match the intensity, passion and neither the finances or atmosphere of the NRL. Players over here earn considerably less than their counterparts down under due to a very low salary cap. This, in addition to other factors such as strict rules on the amount of foreign players a club can own and the risk of these players being ignored by international and state selectors, stops the best NRL players from leaving the sunshine. This is not to say that ex-NRL players in the Super League are of a terrible standard, because they aren't, Super League just cannot seem to lure the Ben Barbas, the Benji Marshalls or the Greg Inglises, the great players in their prime, whereas the NRL successfully manages to poach the best British talent, and it's import rate is growing fast. So far this season alone, at least five English players and one Frenchman from Super League clubs will be starting next season in the NRL, with the prospect of more heading to Australia, including some of the British game's biggest superstars, in the near future. When faced with this fact, worries about the future and sustainability of an appealing British domestic game begin to flare. However the NRL, as I have said, has been the making of many Super League players and so long term benefits on the domestic front can be seen. Many of the players going to NRL recently, such as Wigan's Lee Mossop, have signed contracts that link them directly back to their British club upon their return home. Setups like this allow the player to go and test himself amongst the best and then return to their hometown club better for the experience, and personally I do not see anything wrong with this. The more players who can experience playing against the best week in week out will have incredible value upon their return, and hopefully become catalysts for a more intense competition in the regular season. The international stage, though, is where I see the biggest benefit of the exodus of Super League players. The footballers honing their skills in amongst the stars of Rugby League in the NRL will step up the challenge on the world stage. Australia and New Zealand are without a doubt the top international sides, and it is their players after all who make the NRL what it is. But, there is hope that with a greater influx of English players into the best competition, the English National Team (and hopefully a reformed Great Britain Lions team) can finally give the Antipodeans a good challenge. And with 2013 being the year of the Rugby League World Cup, the sooner this happens the better. We all know we've got the talent, it just needs to be develop and, however painful it is to say this, the challenge does not lie in the rainy heartlands of Rugby League Football - it lies across the world, sun-drenched and well financed, in the NRL.
